p: Although Osteosarcoma (OS) is a rare disease comprising less than 1% of cancers diagnosed in the United States, it is the most common primary malignant bone tumor in adolescents and young adults. OS accounts for 8.9% of cancer-related deaths and carry an overall 5-year survival rate of 60â€“70% despite modern treatment protocols that combine chemotherapy and surgery [ 6, 7]. Chemotherapy has been established as a critical component of OS therapy, but its adverse side effects associated with the drug resistance developed by tumors, lead to the urgent need for new and specific anticancer agents.
